section.title: Position, Displacement, and Distance
section.p: Position refers to the location of the object. If motion occurs only on the x axis, we use x coordinate of the object to locate it. More generally, we can use all the coordinates (x, y, z ) for the point where the object is located if we need to describe motion in three-dimensional space. In motion in the xy-plane, we also use polar coordinates ( r, \theta ).
Displacement is the change in position during an interval. Displacements along coordinates are denoted by \Delta x, \Delta y, and \Delta z.

Suppose, an object moves from x = x_i at initial time t_i to x = x_f at final time t_f , then the displacement will be
\Delta x = x_f - x_i.

Distance traveled refers to the length of the entire path of motion, not just the iunitial and final locations. This is usually denoted by d . The difference between displacement and distance is illustrated in .

statement.p: A boy runs on a straight track, which is taken to be the x axis. As shown in , the boy is at x = 5\text{ m} mark at t = 2 \text{ sec} . He runs to x = 50\text{ m} mark, reaching there at t=10\text{ sec}. He then turns around and runs back to x = 20\text{ m} mark arriving there at t = 20 \text{ sec}.
(a) What is his displacement during the t = 2 \text{ sec} to t = 20 \text{ sec} interval?
(b) How much distance did he travel during the t = 2 \text{ sec} to t = 20 \text{ sec} interval?
(c) What is his displacement during the t = 2 \text{ sec} to t = 10 \text{ sec} interval?
(d) How much distance did he travel during the t = 2 \text{ sec} to t = 10 \text{ sec} interval?
(e) What is his displacement during the t = 10 \text{ sec} to t = 20 \text{ sec} interval?
(f) How much distance did he travel during the t = 10 \text{ sec} to t = 20 \text{ sec} interval?

hint.p: Displacement depends only on the initial and final locations and distance depends on the entirety of motion.

answer.p: (a) \Delta x = 15\text{ m}, (b) d = 75\text{ m}, (c) \Delta x = 45\text{ m}, (d) d = 45\text{ m}, (e) \Delta x = -30\text{ m}, (f) d = 30\text{ m},

solution.p:
(a) The displacement on x axis is the change in the x coordinates.
\Delta x = 20\text{ m} - 5\text{ m} = 15\text{ m}.

(b) The distance traveled on path must take into account all the distance traveled. Here, the boy first ran 50-5 = 45 \text{ m} and then ran another 50 - 20 = 30\text{ m} on the return path. We need to add them.
d = 45 \text{ m} + 30\text{ m} = 75\text{ m}.

(c)The displacement on x axis is the change in the x coordinates.
\Delta x = 50\text{ m} - 5\text{ m} = 45\text{ m}.

(d) Since there is no turn in motion direction during this interval, the distance is equal to the magnitude of displacement.
d = 45\text{ m}.

(e) The displacement on x axis is the change in the x coordinates.
\Delta x = 20\text{ m} - 50\text{ m} = -30\text{ m}.

(f) Since there is no turn in motion direction during this interval, the distance is equal to the magnitude of displacement, stripping away the negative sign.
d = 30\text{ m}.
